I'm Suprised Master Chief didn't show up and mop the whole damn planet .Sequel: Humans return and wipe out the blue heathen treehuggers. Later in history books: "It turned out that their spears were no match for our nukes." I never understood why it was they thought that humanity would just count their losses and leave Pandora alone. If they really wanted that  Unoptanium or whatever it was called, surely they'd send a proper military force next time. When the East India Company failed to secure India, Great Britain annexed it and put it under martial law. A private company nearly wiped out the Na'vi, what's to stop a full military invasion? Just seemed like a bit of a plot hole to me.

Filmi izledikten sonra, doğaya olan sevgim ve saygım kat kat arttı. Efsane ötesi... Her insanın ölmeden önce izlemesi gerek.

Ve şunu da eklemeden edemeyeceğim; yorumları okuduktan sonra, yalnız olmadığımı farkettim. Bu çok sevindirici aslında. Umarım çok zaman geçmeden yaşadığımız dünya, Pandora gibi bir yer olur...

People love a struggle. Whether it's between rivalling ideologies, characters and their morale or a world between itself, the Struggle (TM) is something that's been essential to a story since the gladiators tackled lions.
Avatar has no struggle. It's as shallow as it looks, unless you're looking for a movie that presents a new world with factions and varying characters. And based on the marketing of the films & the game releasing soon (just found out about that), that's all they focus on.
It's simply a matter of reluctance to engage with the story and stay in the worldbuilding process. That's their biggest setback.

Before I get too far into this; the reasons I didn't care much for Ferngully in Space (I don't hate it, I just don't get the appeal) are that the morality play was so obvious with the Noble Savage trope, the lazy naming conventions, and particularly Jake not doing the ONE thing he was supposed to do so he could play around with Natiri. I blame him for the deaths that happened.
I watched a video comparing this movie with a book: "Expedition" by Wayne Barlowe. Can't find it.

I loved the movie for its sound, graphics, special effects, and concept. So mostly as eye candy. But if you want me to be an honest critic when it comes to the actual story building and writing, and propaganda portraying, I’m behind all the criticisms 100%. I can say I enjoyed the movie as a fantasy, ergo “not real or taken seriously.” And if you were an environmentalist radical, political type of person who asked if I took a lesson from the movie, I’ll be like, “Huh! Oh! The propaganda? Yeah, I just filtered that out of my mind and enjoyed it my way.” Captain Planet was not as preachy as this. But correct me if I’m wrong.
my view on the movie is that no matter where humans go they will be destructive and do anything to destroy anything just for profit

ironic part is that the rock they need too mine in the movie is important cause earth is close too being on its last leg. but this first film never addresses it, most people later found out about this from the video game tie in movie logs or scenes that hint about it

Another problem you forgot to mention that we don’t extract resources just for shits and giggles, we do it to power our society even the ancients did this through hunting and mining for stone to build their cities. We didn’t just kill whales for fun we killed them for oil to heat and light our homes and lubricate early industrialized machinery.

The opposite of this is one of the things I love about the Matrix Trilogy, yes including and especially the sequels. 
The Matrix Trilogy do the opposite, particularly in the second and third films, and hit topics from many different angles, though in their case may have gone to far in that direction to where the abstraction and need for audience participation in construction of meaning was possibly too much for audiences overall.

I personally dislike the lack of nuance or complexity in the ideas and do not like the absolute nature of how the sides are represented in the film, I also squirmed and eye rolled during the tribal-medicine-v-human-medicine scene, but symbolically it can still all work, these things may not matter, in terms of making its main big points it may not matter. It makes it’s statements so intensely and definitively that they still land, it’s analogous to an over correction. 
As I mentioned in my previous comment, I do not believe this is what causes audience indifference. There are plenty of films which people love that have ham fisted simplistic ideas, sometimes ridiculous total nonsense messaging and  people still love the movies. 
Sometimes we overthink these things. I think there is an inherent goofiness to the characters in Avatar that is an obstacle, and the writing of these characters that is not compelling enough. I think of it as failing the poster-test. As an adolescent, even child, would you have liked any of these characters enough to have wanted to put a poster of them on your wall? Or to get a figurine of them? 
Avatar doesn’t illicit this response in people because the characters don’t connect deeply enough and I think the aesthetic is still too goofy. The bare asses, the awkward bodies and particular cultural cringiness is off putting. And the Character writing just isn’t strong enough.

Admittedly I’m only 14 minutes into this so have not heard your full hypothesis but I believe what you are highlighting is an issue but not the issue behind the indifference and lack of connection people have with the films. 
Personally I dislike the extreme simplification in the representation of the ideas in the film but it could be argued that it’s simplicity, while unrealistic if taken literally, is symbolically more potent and hits harder and more directly.
It could be intentional rather than lazy.
James Cameron is quite astute and does many things that can appear lazy or dumbed down or even mistakes on purpose, he talks about these things in interviews and his Masterclass. For instance in his Masterclass he explains how he sets up reveals in such a way that the audience can jump ahead and solve the thing a moment before the characters do. I have mixed feelings about this, and the result can be that people criticise such a moment as “saw it coming” as though it failed, not realising Cameron had deliberately adjusted the moment for them to have that experience. So it may be similar in many other cases, such as the simplification and lack of nuance in the ideas in Avatar films.
Either way, I think the issue you highlight is something that comes up later in the post movie talks between viewers rather than something they experience emotionally while watching. I believe the commonly cited indifference to the films is due to other reasons.

I want to disagree with a couple things. 

the bias on imperialism for this video. or maybe more specifically, the hypothetical rewrite. Consumerism is a complex issue, but that never really read as a strong message of the film. at least not on the individual or impoverished level. It's pretty clearly an allegory about corporate greed, not collective human greed. and greed as a 'sin' or motivation isn't ever about money, but what money is. within a capitalist civilization it's power, and those with power will go to extreme ends for more of it or to protect what of it they have. consumerism is a means to that end. the metals used in our electronics come from conflict zones that have been invaded, couped, and otherwise victims of imperialism by primarily the United States (china is doing it in Africa as well). ascribing some virtuous intent to the humans doing the invading of Pandora as if Unobtanium (still dumb) could solve a problem would be pro American imperialism propaganda. having specific characters have personal reasons, like "i've gotta put food on my families plate." to make them more complex would be better writing than what we got. or adding an addendum that the Unobtanium (so dumb) does enable the solution to an environmental catastrophe and they're going to sell it at a crazy markup, and the villain knows this but it's guaranteed his family will get the new technology. because i don't disagree that what we got was poorly written, but i think making the grand motivation of the faction be sympathetic like it's a cruel necessity, gives too much leeway to those doing it on earth in the global south as we speak. 

and that Cameron actually had any real political intent behind it. yes he leans pro ecological, but I genuinely am of the impression that he needed as many butts in seats as he could get to justify the absurd cost of making the first and then the second movies. and that he went with a generic, feelgood story, written by formula to be as inoffensively black and white morally as he could. and didn't really think too critically about it beyond how to broaden appeal. (which even in way of water there's some pretty dumb and basic plotholes that someone of his calibre should have caught.) like, lets be honest, they didn't even change the placeholder name of Unobtanium. that was a page on TvTropes before Avatar was even written.
The cinematography of Avatar is its greatest aspect, no question.

I think you may have missed one of the main points of the movie, whilst they did have consumeristic messaging, one of the bigger main pints you missed was that the movie was an analogy to colonialism. I do not believe the film was nessecarily saying you must live like the indengenous tribes, but more so saying. look what has happened to these people. Likewise with the argument against colonialism, saying that other tribes had cruel and evil practices like slavery these are half truths when compared to the genocides of colonialsm. so seeing colonialism through the story model I believe these depections are more so accurate. tbh i didn't like the franchise for the way it depicted both sides of colonialism. As one of the many people who still are victimized from colonialism. that with me being African.  I didn't like the way the film whitewashed the story of the people. Making it paleatble and almost infantalized. It rubbed me the wrong way that Jake had to be the "white saviour". Almost like the Na'vi couldn't do it themselves. I also didn't like how they accepted him into their tribe, And made him chief. someone who has absolutely no ties to the tribe besides phenotype.  He is one of the sole reasons for the downfall of their people. why should they forgive. The movie to me felt like a white mans fantasy film to yet again place themselves at the forefront of indigenous stories.
